bearing_type.name: Bearing Type
bearing_type.description: The mechanical system that allows the tonearm to move freely in both horizontal and vertical planes.

categories.name: Gimbal
categories.description: A robust and common design using two pairs of bearings on perpendicular axes. Known for stability and solid bass performance.

categories.name: Unipivot
categories.description: The arm balances on a single sharp point. Known for a lively, open, and 'free' sound, but can be more challenging to set up.

categories.name: Knife-Edge
categories.description: The arm rests on a sharp, hardened 'knife' edge. A classic design that aims to combine the stability of a gimbal with low friction.

categories.name: Magnetic
categories.description: Uses magnetic levitation or stabilization for a non-contact pivot. Can be part of a gimbal or unipivot design.

categories.name: Tangential (Air Bearing)
categories.description: A linear tracking arm that moves on a cushion of air, theoretically eliminating tracking error. Complex and expensive.

categories.name: Tangential (Mechanical)
categories.description: A linear tracking arm that moves along a physical rail or mechanism. Aims to eliminate tracking error.

arm_material.name: Armtube Material
arm_material.description: The material used for the main tonearm tube, chosen for its balance of stiffness, low mass, and damping properties.

categories.name: Aluminum
categories.description: The most common material. Offers an excellent balance of performance and cost. Can be straight, tapered, or treated.

categories.name: Carbon Fibre
categories.description: Very light, stiff, and well-damped. Popular in modern low-to-medium mass tonearms.

categories.name: Magnesium
categories.description: Lighter and better-damped than aluminum. Used in high-performance arms like the SME Series V.

categories.name: Titanium
categories.description: Extremely stiff and strong. Used in very high-end arms, often for critical parts or the entire tube.

categories.name: Stainless Steel
categories.description: Very rigid and heavy. Often used in high-mass tonearms designed for low-compliance cartridges.

categories.name: Wood
categories.description: Used for its unique resonance characteristics and natural damping. Can provide a warm, organic sound.

headshell_connector.name: Headshell Connector Type
headshell_connector.description: The type of connection used for removable headshells.

categories.name: Integrated
categories.description: The headshell is a fixed, non-removable part of the armtube. Offers maximum rigidity but less flexibility.

categories.name: SME / Universal 4-Pin
categories.description: The industry standard bayonet connector, also known as H-4. Allows for easy swapping of cartridges mounted on different headshells.

categories.name: Proprietary
categories.description: A unique connector specific to the manufacturer (e.g., some Dual, Lenco, or B&O models).
